Authors:
Mark Alan Buchheim, Haley Johnson, Ashley Silver, Richard
Portman, Matthew Toomey
Title: A new species of Haematococcus from North America
Keywords:
Ettlia, Haematococcus, Palmella, Akinete, Zoospore,
Mullers Ratchet, Polyploidy, Pyrenoid, Flagellar collar, rbcL, 18S rRNA,
26S rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, ITS-1, ITS-2, Astaxanthin, Ketocarotenoid,
HPLC.
Abstract:
Haematococcus is a green flagellate that transitions to an
akinete stage that accumulates valuable ketocarotenoids. An enormous
body of research is focused on finding ways to commercialize the
pigments produced by Haematococcus, often without the benefit of a sound
phylogenetic assessment of the strains. Thus, comparing results of these
efforts may be confounded by the absence of an updated phylogenetic
framework. The goal of this investigation was to reconstruct the
phylogeny of an expanded sampling of Haematococcus isolates utilizing
data from the 18S and 26S rRNA genes, from the internal transcribed
spacers (ITS-1 and ITS-2), from the 5.8S rRNA gene and from the rbcL
gene. The expanded data and taxon sampling presented here support the
concept of a new speciesH. privus (sp. nov). The new species is
comprised of several isolates of Haematococcus collected exclusively in
North America. Results from analyses of morphological data indicate that
ratios of protoplast length to width and akinete diameter may be useful
tools for discriminating new Haematococcus lineages. Although variances
were often too great to draw conclusions, H. rubicundus showed the
highest yields for total carotenoids and astaxanthin. The total evidence
supports the existence of at least five, species-level lineages in the
genus. The updated phylogenetic assessment presented here will help
applied researchers frame their investigations of Haematococcus in an
updated evolutionary context. However, a number of surprising
observations regarding polyploidy, sexuality and chloroplast genomics in
Haematococcus suggest that this simple, green unicell has a few secrets
left to be revealed.
